title: Amazing Grace

musicalLanguage.description: The most widely recognized hymn in the English-speaking world. Words by John Newton (1772), a former slave ship captain who found faith. The melody — likely of Scottish or Irish origin — is pentatonic: just five notes (G, A, B, D, E). That simplicity is its power. No chromatic tension, no dissonance. Pure, open, and universal.
musicalLanguage.structure: Four 4-bar phrases (ABAC form): A rises from G to D, B reaches the peak on high D and descends, A returns, C resolves with a gentle descent to the tonic. This arrangement covers the complete first verse — the melody everyone knows.
keyMoments: Measure 1: The pickup — G3 alone, the lowest note, rising. A voice beginning to speak.
Measures 2-5: First phrase — the melody rises from B3 through D4 to B4. An arc of hope.
Measures 6-9: Second phrase — the melody reaches D5, the highest point. The peak of 'grace'.
Measures 10-13: Third phrase — the melody returns to the opening, but we hear it differently now.
Measures 14-18: Final phrase — the melody descends gently to G4. Home. Rest.
teachingGoals: Pentatonic melody: only G, A, B, D, E are used. No C, no F#. This is the sound of folk music worldwide.
3/4 waltz time: three beats per measure. Feel the gentle sway — ONE two three, ONE two three.
Legato phrasing: connect every note to the next. No gaps. The melody should sing.
Simple chord accompaniment: I (G), IV (C), V (D) — the three chords of folk music.
Dynamic arc: start soft, build to the peak, settle back. The music breathes.
styleTips: This is a hymn. Sing it in your mind as you play. If the melody doesn't sing, slow down.
The simplicity is the difficulty. Every note must be placed with intention.
Sustain pedal on beat 1 of each measure, lift on beat 3. Let the harmony bloom.
The left hand should be felt, not heard. Gentle chords underneath the melody.
No rubato in the middle of phrases. Save any tempo flexibility for phrase endings.

measures.teachingNote: The pickup — G3 alone on beat 3. One note, unaccompanied. This is the voice beginning to speak. In 3/4 time, beat 3 is the weakest beat — the melody starts from humility.
B3 held for two beats, then D4 — the melody takes its first step upward. Left hand enters with G major: G2, B2, D3. The harmony arrives gently.
G4 — a leap of a fourth from D4. The melody opens up. Then E4 — a step back down. The contour rises and sighs.
G4 again, then E4 — the same figure over C major (IV chord). The melody repeats but the harmony underneath changes, giving it new color.
D4 descends to B3 — the first phrase settles. Back on G major. This is the end of the first 'A' phrase: the melody has risen from G3 to G4 and fallen back to B3. A complete arc.
The B phrase begins — same opening as measure 2 (B3 to D4) but this time the melody will climb higher.
G4 and E4 — familiar territory. The melody is building toward its peak.
D5 — the highest note in the piece. The peak of the melody. Over D major (V chord), the harmony supports the climax. B4 follows — beginning the descent. This is the emotional center.
D5 again, then B4 — the melody lingers at the peak before descending. Over G major now — the harmony has resolved while the melody stays high.
The third phrase (A return) — B4 to G4. The melody descends. We've heard this shape before but an octave higher. Recognition and variation.
A4 to B4 — a gentle upward step over D major. The A note is the only note that isn't in the G major chord — it adds a touch of tension, a gentle pull.
G4 to E4 over C major (IV chord). The same sigh figure as measure 3, but now it carries the weight of the whole melody behind it.
D4 to B3 — settling back. The third phrase resolves the same way as the first. The symmetry is comforting.
The final phrase (C) begins. B3 to D4 — one last time ascending. The melody has one more thing to say.
G4 to E4 — the familiar sigh over C major. The gentlest version yet.
D4 to E4 — a small upward step over D major. Instead of falling, the melody lifts slightly, creating a sense of continued motion.
D4 to B3 — the penultimate gesture. The melody descends toward home.
G3 — the final note. The same note where we began. The melody has traveled a full octave up and returned to where it started. Hold this note and let it fade. The silence after is part of the music.

source: Arrangement: AI Jam Session. Traditional melody, words by John Newton (1772).
